stem: A 62-year-old client with an acute myocardial infarction (MI) is receiving a continuous intravenous (IV) heparin infusion. Based on the documentation in the Serial Coagulation & Heparin Dose Log, what is the nurse's next action?

options.text: Maintain the current infusion rate with no changes.
Increase the infusion rate by 2 units/kg/hr.
Decrease the infusion rate by 2 units/kg/hr.
Stop the infusion and notify the healthcare provider of the high activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

rationale.correct: The client's current aPTT (52 seconds) is within the therapeutic goal range of 1.5 to 2.5 times the baseline. Given the baseline aPTT of 32 seconds, the therapeutic range is 48 to 80 seconds. According to the heparin titration protocol provided in the exhibit, an aPTT within the range of 48 to 80 seconds requires 'No change in rate.'
clinicalPearls: Heparin prevents new clot formation but does not dissolve existing clots.
The therapeutic range for heparin is typically 1.5 to 2.5 times the control/baseline aPTT.
Protamine sulfate is the antidote for heparin overdose.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming an aPTT of 52 seconds is 'high' because it exceeds the general reference range (25-35 seconds).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In the context of heparin therapy, 'high' refers to the therapeutic goal, not the general reference range. For a patient receiving heparin, the blood is intentionally 'thinned' to achieve a therapeutic effect.

mnemonic.title: Hep-PTT
mnemonic.expansion: Heparin (7 letters) is associated with PTT (3 letters). This mnemonic helps to remember the lab test used to monitor heparin therapy.

exhibits.title: Heparin Titration Protocol
exhibits.content:
Goal aPTT: 1.5 to 2.5 times the baseline (48 - 80 seconds).
Titration:
- aPTT < 48 seconds: Increase rate by 2 units/kg/hr.
- aPTT 48 to 80 seconds: No change in rate.
- aPTT > 80 seconds: Decrease rate by 2 units/kg/hr.

exhibits.title: Nurses Notes
exhibits.content: 2015: Heparin infusion currently at 12 units/kg/hr. No signs of bleeding observed. Puncture sites are clean and dry. Oral mucosa is intact.
